dc:description:
*USP25* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant epilepsy in 2024 in a single paper (Fan 2024, PMID: 38875478) describing 5 probands with variants in this gene and various types of seizures, intellectual disability and normal brain MRIs. The reported variants included one nonsense, one 3-base pair deletion, and three missense variants; 3 of these variants were inherited from a parent with seizure history (PMID: 38875478). Per gnomAD v4.1, *USP25* is not constrained for either missense or loss of function variation, and none of the variants reported in Fan et al. had any convincing supportive functional information. Some of the reported variants were also present in gnomAD. Because of this, the case-level data was not considered strong enough to score.

*USP25* encodes a deubiquitinating enzyme that is involved in protein degradation. The functional impact of these variants on the ubiquitination pathway was examined in HEK293T cells and was not consistent. In addition, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures was difficult to interpret. Functional studies of the nonsense variant showed that the truncated protein was produced, stable, and showed a possible dominant-negative or gain-of-function effect. In addition, a knock-out mouse model was generated but did not exhibit spontaneous seizures, which was not considered an appropriate model by this GCEP and therefore was not scored. Also, the study focused on homozygous knock-out mice whereas all reported individuals carried heterozygous variants. The homozygous knock-out model did show a higher propensity for seizures when induced compared to wild-type; however, this loss-of-function model did not fit with the possible dominant-negative or gain-of-function disease mechanism postulated for the nonsense variant. 
 
In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between *USP25*  and autosomal dominant epilepsy has been disputed, and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role *USP25* plays in epilepsy. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Epilepsy Gene Curation Expert Panel on April 1, 2025 (SOP version 11).
curationReasonDescription: Case-level data was not considered strong enough to score. Functional data was not consistent among the variants and was difficult to interpret in relationship to a seizure phenotype. The knock-out mouse model did not exhibit spontaneous seizures so was not scored.

evidence.dc:description: Functional studies of this variant showed that the truncated protein was produced, stable, and showed a possible dominant-negative or gain-of-function effect, thus not a true null variant. Functional impact on the ubiquitination pathway was examined but was not consistent among the variants. Also, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures is difficult to interpret. Due to the above points, the Epilepsy GCEP decided not to score this variant.

Variant is present in gnomAD v4.1. Functional impact on the ubiquitination pathway was examined but was not consistent among the variants. Also, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures is difficult to interpret. Due to the above points, the Epilepsy GCEP decided not to score this variant.

Also, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures is difficult to interpret. Due to the above points, the Epilepsy GCEP decided not to score this variant.

Also, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures is difficult to interpret. Due to the above points, the Epilepsy GCEP decided not to score this variant.

Variant is present in gnomAD v4.1. Functional impact on the ubiquitination pathway was examined but was not consistent among the variants. Also, the significance of these functional studies in relationship to seizures is difficult to interpret. Due to the above points, the Epilepsy GCEP decided not to score this variant.

This knock-out model did not have spontaneous seizures, which is not considered an appropriate model by this GCEP and therefore was not scored. The knock-out model did show a higher propensity for seizures when induced compared to wild type; however, this loss-of-function model does not fit with the possible dominant-negative or gain-of-function disease mechanism postulated for the nonsense variant. In addition, the study focused on homozygous knockout mice when all reported patients have been found with heterozygous variants.

This knock-out model did not have spontaneous seizures but did show a higher propensity for seizures when induced compared to wild type.  Latency time to the first seizure and duration time was significantly different between the knockout mice compared to the wild type.
evidence.rdfs:label: Fan knock-out mouse model
